First off, I want to commend the art team on this book: great text layout, gorgeous pictures, and excellent paper. But beyond the visual appeal, I'm at a loss for praise.Granted, as an intermediate level cook, it doesn't look like I'm the target audience for his Food Revolution campaign, but I was bewildered to find recipes for things like plain oatmeal, boiled eggs, smoothies, and white rice. I know he's assuming only a passing familiarity with the stove, but many of these "recipes" can be found on the sides of packages. And the vast majority of the other recipes are lackluster -- salads, various grilled/roasted meats, omelets, vegetables with herbs & butter, sauces for ice-cream. The only interesting dishes were in the curries section, and for that I'd be better served by a Madhur Jaffrey cookbook.I was also surprised to find many recipes required fairly premium items like filet mignon, sun-dried tomatoes, jarred roasted red peppers, and cr√®me fraiche. By no means were ALL the recipes so posh, but for a book that touts "simple, affordable meals", they seemed fairly out of place.Overall, the cookbook delivers basic variations on basic themes which, frankly, left me bored and uninspired. Beginner cooks might find some value in the visuals, but for comprehensive lessons in technique (and excellent recipes to boot) I would steer them towards Mark Bittman's How to Cook Everything: Simple Recipes for Great Food.

I bought this cookbook after watching Jamie Oliver's Food Revolution documentary series. I'm from West Virginia and it was filmed about 3 hours away from me in Huntington, WV. I loved the tv series and everything he had to say about nutrition, so I couldn't resist supporting Jamie and attempting to make my life more healthy.I easily found all of the ingredients from the recipes I've cooked at my local Kroger. It seemed a little expensive when I went shopping, but each recipe seems to last for days. I actually started cutting them in half since I only feed my boyfriend and myself. Jamie added a lot of pictures of the cooking process for every recipe. That was extremely helpful. I hadn't cooked with a lot of the vegetables he uses, so they often looked very strange (almost disgusting). But his photographs showed me I was doing everything correctly and that his looked just as strange. It was also nice to see the sizes he would "chop" "slice" and "cut" things into.There were so many great recipes, and I haven't even cooked everything in it yet. My favorite: Pot-Roast Meatloaf. I've made it many times. First for myself, then for family dinners and potlucks.I also loved the chapter on Indian food. My favorite type of food is Indian. Jamie made the recipes so easy and still filled with all those Indian flavors.

Absolutely outstanding. This is now my favorite cookbook, and I'll be buying it if I don't receive it for Christmas. So far I've made the meatballs, banana oatmeal, scrambled eggs, and chickan tikka masala curry. The one time I tried to make meatballs before this recipe, I overcooked them and they fell apart in the pasta. Following the directions from this book, my meatballs became fragrant with rosemary and held together well. My husband loved them. The oatmeal was delicious, and the scrambled eggs recipe yielded perfect scrambled eggs. Actually, I've always always overcooked my eggs and my husband never really liked them, so he was thrilled with the results this time around. I was hesitant to try making curry, because I doubted I could make it as good as the kind we get as take-out, but it was also perfect. I think the cilantro/yogurt/almond toppings really helped to make it so yummy. There are colorful photos for EVERY recipe, usually at least several of the process, which I appreciated so much. The recipes do rely heavily on fresh herbs, but I was able to find a lot of things out of the book that I could make on a tight grocery budget, with some small substitutions (plain eggs instead of cage-free/organic, etc).

I started reading several books last week, most of them novels, but the book that got me the most excited was‚Äìof all things‚Äìa cookbook. I decided to order this book from the library after watching a couple episodes of ‚ÄúJamie Oliver‚Äôs Food Revolution,‚Äù a show where the British chef comes to the American South and tries to reform the disgusting eating habits of the unhealthiest town in the world. Jamie Oliver reveals and rebukes the greasy, processed food that Americans eat, trying to turn over a new leaf in the school lunch program at a public elementary school.After waiting more than two months for my hold request to be fulfilled (as the 24th person in line at the library), I finally picked up my copy of the cookbook, Jamie‚Äôs Food Revolution: Rediscover How to Cook Simple, Delicious, Affordable Meals. Cookbooks aren‚Äôt generally a ‚Äúread-it-from-cover-to-cover‚Äù item, but I found that this was one cookbook I couldn‚Äôt put down. Jamie begins by telling the novice chef what tools every good kitchen should contain and what ingredients every pantry should be stocked with. (I made some notes on the latter for my next trip to Winco.) Then he launches into the recipes.The first section listed off a handful of twenty minute meals for people who are short on time. With names like ‚ÄúShrimp and Avacado with an Old-School Marie Rose Sauce,‚Äù I found that they did indeed look simple and delicious, though maybe not quite as affordable as our usual fare. The next section of the book was even more intriguing: ‚ÄúQuick Pasta.‚Äù The pasta dishes I usually make are a last-ditch resort born of empty cupboards and small imagination. Jamie offers exciting dishes like ‚ÄúBroccoli and Pesto Tagliatelle,‚Äù containing only a handful of ingredients but looking mouthwateringly delicious in the full color pictures.The book proceeded with ‚ÄúTasty Stir-Fries‚Äù and ‚ÄúEasy Curries.‚Äù I resolved then and there that I was going to make a curry that week, something I had never before attempted. A few days later I produced a passable ‚ÄúChicken Tikka Masala,‚Äù with a lovely sauce and decent chicken (that would probably have been more tender if my stovetop had a more even heat).The next section contained recipes for salads. This exemplified what I love about Jamie Oliver‚Äôs book‚Äìversatility. In the salad section, he tries to teach you general rules so that you can whip up your own salad creation. The full-color chart on page 119 has six rows of ‚Äúkinds‚Äù of ingredients: soft, crunchy, herby, veggies, cheese, and toppings. Each of the rows contains four items; for instance, the ‚Äúherby‚Äù row has mint, basil, italian parsley, and arugula. All you need to do is pick one ingredient from each row to come up with an awesome salad! There are literally hundreds of combinations to choose from.The second recipe that I cooked from this book was the ‚ÄúBeef and Ale Stew,‚Äù and I must say that it turned out divine! The portions for most of the main dishes are for 4-6 servings, so we have half of the stew in the freezer waiting for another day. Yesterday, I was sorely tempted to take it out and heat it up for lunch, but I resisted‚Äìknowing, that someday soon, I would want to put a delicious dinner on the table without doing any work.I highly recommend this cookbook to beginner and expert chefs alike. I like it so much that I ordered my own copy from Amazon.com. It should get here later this week.

I have been watching his TV show as well as downloading his podcast from the Minestry of Food and it has been so fun to get into the ease of these recipies. I am an experienced home cook but this book put a lot of great and really easy ideas into play for me. Philip, who never cooks much has taken to making dinners on Sat night and made the Chicken Chow Mein and it was seriously one of the best stir-frys I have eaten! Even our kids chowed down without complaint.(and there was "green stuff" it it. I think Jamie Oliver is a serious pioneer of food reform in the UK and I respect him highly for the work he does getting school kids, the government and the common person to *think* about what they are eating and where it came from.

Oh look, I'm British and my Mommy and Daddy let me cook in their restaurant and now I write books with a sprinkle of this and a handful of that. Listen Jamie Oliver, don't call it a Food Revolution if you require alfalfa flour and ketchup in the same recipe or worse yet, call for canned goods as main ingredients. He should be ashamed of himself.

As the cover suggests, 'Revolution' finds our hero behind the Iron Curtain attempting to introduce his own brand of music to the Soviets, called Wok n Roll.Will he succeed? Or will he plummet headfirst into some borscht? What will his children think of his terrible taste in shirts? This and many more questions left unanswered.

I have tried several recipes from this book now and overall I have been pleased with the results. The only flaw with this book is the way the method has been written, it can be very confusing and difficult to follow.

There are some recipes in this cookbook that fit the criteria of Simple, Delicious, and Affordable.Almost every chapter features multiple dishes that involve expensive cuts of meat like filet mignon, or expensive fish like salmon. Also, while the book is generally good about giving pictures of how to perform some of the more uncommon culinary techniques (like butterflying), the fact of the matter is that I wouldn't have someone try a recipe (or even look at a recipe) that involves butterflying until they'd figured out cutting, chopping, dicing and mincing. Butterflying requires dexterity and a really sharp knife, and if you don't have those (and I'd frankly expect most people to not have those), then it's not something your average reader (who Jamie claims he's shooting for) should be trying to do.That said, the very first chapter of the book, where Jamie gives a list of (to use Alton Brown's terminology) useful and necessary hardware for your kitchen is incredibly useful and valuable. With the exception of the mortar and pestle, with this assortment of equipment, you have absolutely everything you need to learn to cook. The cupboard list is okay too, though I'd probably recommend dropping the Marmite or Vegemite for peanut butter.

Those who know me are aware that I have been preaching what's in this book for years. Jamie (as shown in his recent TV reality series) exhorts that, like Britain, we are killing ourselves with food. This book combats the modern American notion that healthy food is flavorless, too expensive, and too time consuming for the masses. In the introduction, he says a few words about the Ministry of Food in Britain during WWII. I‚Äôll let you all read it but, essentially, it was a government department set up to provide citizens with nutritious meals with their given rations and home gardens. Since that time Britain and America has moved away from the institution of home as hearth. Our hectic lives push us away from the common ground of mealtime. Working long hours far from our homes, extracurricular activities like travel sports demanding ever more time on the road or at practice, both parents working or single-parenthood all serve to separate us from our families, loved ones and our kitchens. Jamie proposes a pyramid scheme, grass roots approach to get us back to the dinner table. Learn how to prepare a few simple, quick, nutritious meals and pass it on.

This book was a life changer. I'd been cooking since I was young but when I went to college I got into the way of relying on convenience and pre-packaged, processed foods, mostly cos I was single. I got this book when I started my family and havent looked back. We have tried most of the recipes and enjoy around a dozen staples with themed nights to simplify meal planning, curry or chinese night, retro night, roasts or meatloaf on sundays and soups, salads through the week. I havent had takeaways in over a year cos home made is easier, cheaper n healthier. I am a huge fan of Jamie Oliver as he has revolutionised how my family come together, prepare food and enjoy meals together. It started with this book, his subsequent books 30 minute meals and save with Jamie have offered more family favourites. My husbands home made pizza is way better than any you could buy. Jamie Oliver is our hero:-)

What sets this book apart from other cookbooks today is the attitude it's written with and the way it's organized. If more cookbooks preached, as this one does, that cooking isn't too hard and you don't have to be whipping up magazine worthy food to even bother, we wouldn't have the problems we're having. It would stave off not only obesity and diabetes but the unbelievable tidal wave of people who don't know how to cook anymore. I cannot believe how many of them I meet nowadays.The other beauty of the book is its structure - chapters like 'pasta', 'curries', 'humble ground beef' actually tell you a few new things to do with old stuff, so even if you cook quite a bit, htis book is inspirational. It's going to become my standard gift to new married couples from now on.

I've been a fan of Jamie Oliver for a long time but I have yet to purchase one of his cookbooks. I won't be buying this but it is a nice cookbook with colorful illustrations. I only made one of the recipes and it was a simple one. I need Jamie to come over and give me a cooking lesson in person! Or I'd be only too happy to go back to London and meet him there - ha!

Blech. Hoped it would be better than this. I like the idea of good food cooked at home to feed families, but I didn't like the recipes. And honestly, I can't take one more vow in my life right now (learn one recipe from each chapter, vow to teach it to at least two more people). I get it Jamie, but honestly...

This is a nice book, but many of the recipes weren't for my family. I'm game for most foods, but my family are very much "meat and potatoes," so many of the more non-traditional fare (like aloo gobhi) wouldn't fly in my household. I wish that wasn't the case. Good (British) recipes promoting better eating habits and more affordable ingredients.

Jamie Oliver gets me really excited about cooking as a basic, essential aspect of a happy life. I DESERVE TO EAT A HOME-COOKED MEAL THAT ISN'T RAMEN! YES, JAMIE, YES I DO!This book also features some harried, working-class individuals who learned to cook for themselves and it's sort of heartwarming.
This is a great cookbook. It certainly let's a new cook know how to make good home cooked food. I particularly like the curry section and the salad section. However, the recipes are not that simple!
Pretty good cook book! Easy recipes and delish!

Before I graduated, I knew how to cook two things: eggs and boxed macaroni and cheese. Then my sister bought me Jamie Oliver‚Äôs simplest cookbook for Christmas‚Äîthe one with a back flap that promises, ‚Äúanyone can learn to cook.‚Äù Within weeks, I went from eating Chipotle every night to cooking chicken tikka masala and spaghetti bolognese. This change was good for my diet, but it was also good for my social life. I started inviting people over for dinner two or three times a week. That was how I started to build a new social life after college. ‚ÄîCaroline (https://www.bookish.com/articles/five...)
Very easy to follow, an ideal book for someone who is trying to learn how to cook. It was recommended by my neighbour.

The focus of Food Revolution is the idea of getting people who don't cook or don't cook much or who mainly just order take out or buy ready-made to start cooking. Oliver's trying to show that cooking doesn't have to be complicated or time consuming and that it's healthier and tastier than ready-made or take out.Oliver also puts forth the idea that people who buy the books should learn some of the recipes and then pass them on to other people so that they'll start cooking as well. So here's me passing on a recipe I tried tonight:Jamie Oliver's Asian-style Steamed Salmonserves 2a large handful of broccolini or broccoli rabe1 x 8-oz can of water chestnutsa large handful of sugar snap peas2 salmon fillets, skin on, scaled and bones removed (about 7-oz each, though I used more vegetables and only about 100 g fish)a thumb-sized piece of ginger root1 clove of garlic1/2 a fresh red chile1 scallion2 tbsp soy sauce3 tbsp olive oil1 lemonTo prepare the salmon:If you have a steamer basket, add water to a saucepan just below the level of the basket. If you don't but have a metal colander, add water about half way up a saucepan that will hold it. Put water on high heat to boil. Trim the ends off the broccolini. (I used broccoli because it's what I had, cut to florets). Drain water chestnuts in a colander or through the steamer basket. Add washed sugar snap peas. Lay the salmon fillets, skin side down, on top of them, then scatter the broccoli over. Cover the colander with aluminum foil and scrunch tightly around the edges to seal the steam in.To cook your salmon and make your dressing:Put the colander or steamer basket (with lid) over your pan of boiling water and let it steam for 8 to 10 minutes. While that's happening, peel and grate the ginger and half the clove of garlic into a small bowl. Finely slice your chile (I used a serrano pepper, because it's what I could get) and scallion and add them to the bowl with the soy sauce and olive oil. Squeeze the juice from half a lemon into the bowl. Mix together with a spoon and set aside. After your salmon and vegetables have been steaming for 8 minutes, peel back the foil to check the fish it cooked through, it should flake apart.To serve your salmon:Divide the salmon, water chestnuts, and veggies between your plates or bowls. Give the dressing a quick stir and drizzle it over. Serve with the remaining lemon half, cut into wedges, for squeezing over.Oliver also suggests using cod in place of the salmon and asparagus or asparagus, peas, and greens in place of the broccoli and snap peas. I think it'd probably be quite nice like that.

I am a big fan of Jamie Oliver. I've watched him on cooking shows and on his series "Jamie Oliver's Food Revolution," so I know that he had a lot to offer regarding cooking techniques as well as fantastic ways to motivate people. So when I discovered this book at our local library, I just knew I needed to read it! Many of his recipes are a bit more complicated than I normally cook, but a lot of others follow along the same lines as what I do already. So I found some challenges and a nice reassurance that I'm already headed in the right direction as far as trying to feed my family home-cooked, nourishing and healthy meals. Since he is English, it makes sense that a lot of his recipes have a British flavor (or should I say flavour?) This is good for me, but in our family, I have to accommodate different preferences. So I expect that I will try a few of my favorite recipes (especially when I'm cooking for myself) and a few of the ones I think our family will be open to trying and hope that they approve. I made a family favorite last night - the Thai Green Curry (with a few modifications, like using a bit of curry paste, since it is difficult to get lemongrass and kaffir lime leaves). I also made it with pork rather than shrimp, but we like it with just about any meat (chicken, tofu, etc.) I liked the vegetables that he added (I've never made it with asparagus and snow peas before, but with fresh Spring asparagus, it was fantastic!) and I appreciated his tips, since I'm always trying to make the sauce taste more like what we've eaten in Thailand! Overall, I like his approach to this book. I love the idea that by passing down recipes to one another, we can create a world of cooks, rather than a world of fast-food eaters. If nothing else, I hope to teach our girls that cooking homemade meals is simple and worth the effort. I agree that the times mentioned on the recipes might be a bit optimistic, especially for a novice cook. But with a little prep and some practice, you can easily put together a hot, fresh meal in about 20-30 minutes. I'm not a big fan of television, but I am looking forward to seeing the second season of "Jamie Oliver's Food Revolution" soon.

Oliver‚Äôs most recent book is a spin off from the British version of his Food Revolution television series. (He later did versions of the same show in the US and Australia.) This cookbook is meant to serve as a guidebook for those willing to engage in the Food Revolution by getting back in the kitchen and cooking from-scratch recipes for ourselves and our families. The introduction asks the reader to sign a pledge not only to use the recipes but to pass them on to at least 2, preferably 4 people. In this way, Oliver hopes to continue the Food Revolution movement across the Westernized, English-speaking world.The directions are simple, the pictures are lovely and incredibly helpful, and the dishes look scrumptious. The recipes include a wide range of ethnicities (including a whole chapter on curries) and most appear to be pretty accessible to Americans (burgers, stir fries, fish). There are a few solid British classics as well, such as fish pie, salmon cakes, and Ground Beef Wellington. While the emphasis is on dinner, also included are recipes for breakfast (such as one-cup pancakes) and desserts (raspberry cheesecake).Oliver‚Äôs emphasis isn‚Äôt necessarily always low-fat - one recipe consists primarily of melted cheese, olive oil, and pasta noodles. His objective is more to get people cooking with real ingredients, and believes that better health will follow suit. Indeed! His chapter on vegetables looks capable of converting even the staunchest veggie-haters. Check it out! Now to pass it on. Anyone want a cooking lesson? :-)

I thoroughly enjoyed working my way through Oliver's descriptions and instructions (esp. descriptions such as adding a "lug" of this and that when preparing certain dishes) contained in Jamie's Food Revolution. These are recipes for simple, relatively healthful, and straightforward dishes and condiments that are accompanied by short testimonials from the assorted average Joes/Jills who Jamie's crew taught with the condition that they share their successes. Likewise, he asks readers to "pass it on" once they've mastered a recipe or series of dishes that they particularly enjoy. In the current economy, these are pretty straightforward recipes that will appeal to a range of tastes. I'd definitely consider giving this as a gift to anyone setting out in their first apartment/group house who is living on a budget (who isn't?) and getting increasingly comfortable in the kitchen. I found several yummy items that we'll be tackling in the next few months at our house, including: macaroni and cauliflower cheese bake, vindaloo, cilantro and lime rice, evolution tomato salad, sweet potato and chorizo soup, parsnip and ginger soup, chili con carne, his roast beef and roast pork recipes, broccoli with Asian dressing, baked French potatoes, cherry tomato, caper and balsamic sauce (suitable for serving with fish, meat, or pasta), and fruit scones. Finally, the book is well illustrated with color photos--something I always appreciate when either prepping a new dish or looking for ideas.

The messianic philosophy about "passing it on" is grating and condescending, other than that, it is an excellent source for new cooks and motivating experienced cooks to get out their ruts.I've tried about half a dozen of the recipes and my family enjoyed them all. Most of the recipes use a few common and inexpensive ingredients. "Sunday dinner" recipes use more expensive cuts of meat or fish, but nothing extraordinary. Also key to the success - "close enough" measuring, cutting and cooking time wins, no high precision needed.The photographs really make the book. The format is similar to a comic book - two pages per recipe: one big finished product image, and 6 to 9 step-by-step photos, with no text, shows how the dish is assembled. It is very easy to really see how to brown the onions, or how "done" meat will look. In the main panel, the actual recipe gives clear directions. The author has some videos on his website. He enthusiastically goes on and on and on about how yummy or fan-tas-tic cooking is. Luckily this chatter is contained to a few pages in each chapter. The recipes themselves are free of food-as-religion polemics.New cooks (I'm thinking Boy Scouts working on their cooking merit badge) can feel accomplished after trying a few of the recipes out.

I like this book a lot and have used it frequently over the last few years. He manages to succeed in keeping things simple yet varied with a limited selection of ingredients. Not quite as pernickety as some of his earlier books. Plus, I like the cooking ethos he's trying to promote in this book. Good for family meals, ideas and for those with limited cooking experience (there's some fairly basic stuff in there I skip over).The sizzling beef with spring onions and black bean sauce is divine and I could eat masses of it. Plus, it's the first egg fried rice recipe that seems to work for me.I've done most of these by now. Some favourites?- salmon tikka- mac/cauliflower cheese (my slightly altered version but a good start)- cauliflower cheese soup (gorgeous)- most of the other soups are pretty good too- baked creamy leaks- the mince section is good for inspiration and I think the meatballs work best though I've made the bolognese plenty of times- the basic stew recipe isn't bad to experiment with - spanish style griddled steak works a treat- moroccan lamb- pan fried curried cod- salmon fishcakesMmmmmm. Pretty good book. He looks kind of weird and plasticy on the front cover though.

I wholeheartedly agree with the concept behind this book. Get people back in the kitchen, cooking dinner from scratch. To that end this book had a lot of very useful information (e.g. basic directions on how to cook rice, or how long to boil an egg) . One of the great things about the recipes in this book is that they, not only are easy to make, but make great jumping off points. They don't use any weird ingredients. The book is British and therefore contains a lot of recipes for fish and lamb, which are somewhat harder to come by in rural Alberta. I have made the sweet 'n' sour pork, and the chicken stew and will be making them again. Also, probably the chicken fajitas. I also tried the macaroni and cauliflower cheese bake and pan-fried glazed pork chops with limited success. There are just two complaints with this book. 1) There is not enough vegetable dishes. Depending on your point of view this is or is not a problem. This book was definitely made for carnivores. 2) The recipe instructions are written as one paragraph. Which makes it difficult when picking along the steps as you work. Still, worthwhile taking a look at. I'm still on the fence about buying it.

This book simply doesn't hold its promise, hence the lowest mark. It is plagued by so many unacceptable drawbacks: too many ingredients per dish, too much equipment required, some dishes simply inedible (I hope for Jamie's life that no Italian ever comes across the baked camembert pasta one), others way too fancy for a beginner handbook (Chinese water chestnut soup...); sauce and rice variations which the layman may not know how to combine; as for recipes including Patak's readymade curries, I personally think there are more interesting and genuine ways to tackle Indian cuisine. To sum it up, I ended up with precious little practical knowledge onboard and a vague tiredness of cooking. This is not to say you won't find a few very good recipes: his sweet & sour pork; sizzling beef with black bean sauce; chicken fajitas... not enough to set off the shortcomings, unfortunately. Jamie is undoubtedly a talented man and his intent a laudable one; however, as he humbly implies in the introduction, teaching in book form is definitely not his thing.To get familiar with basic dishes and food processing without a massive headache, I recommend J.-F. Mallet's "Simplissime: The Easiest French Cookbook in the world".

So far I'm loving this book! His enthusiasm has inspired me to get back to family dinners at the table with good food which I'd fallen out of habit of since my daughters growing up and moving out on their own and the discovery of gluten and dairy intolerances that were making cooking such a chore. So much of what I cooked before was dependent on one or both of gluten or dairy that I was at a loss as to what to cook. It seemed everything had to change and all my old reliable standby recipes were a thing of the past so that when the question of 'what to make for dinner' would be inevitably asked of myself every damn day I'd have no idea. My mind was an abyss.  Now that my son's girlfriend and 2 year old daughter are living with us the family is growing and changing again and it's time to get back to the joy,and let's be honest, the labour of family meals, much to my husband's great delight. This book and Jamie's program Meals in 30 Minutes has been a huge help if for no other reason then to have an answer finally, to the damned, inevitable question as to what am I going to make for dinner tonight.

Don't let the two star review steer you away from at least glancing through this book. I gave it two because it wasn't telling me anything I didn't already know. I know I need a whisk in my kitchen. I know how to make scrambled eggs (and probably wouldn't put that in a cookbook if I only had 360 pages).However, there's a certain **cough cough** level of budding chef that might give this a read and be able to say without question that this book changed their life. It had beautiful photographs throughout, sometimes even illustrating the various steps in the cooking process. The organization makes a lot of sense, with sections like, "Twenty-minute meals," "Easy curries," "Comforting Stews" (even though there was only one actual recipe in that section,) and "Quick-cooking meat and fish." The introduction at the beginning reads as a pleading essay from Oliver asking the readers to 
pass it on
 (meaning pass on the recipes within to friends) in order to stop obesity. A nice gesture, Mr. Oliver, however I know very few early-twenty-somethings will be cooking together.

Jamie Oliver is a chef who lives for simplicity and taste. In Jamie's Ministry of Food: Anyone can learn to cook in 24 hours, Jamie Oliver sets out to teach people who don't cook or beginners how to cook simple and easy foods (which might seem out of your grasp). I will admit I am not a beginner cook, but enjoyed the style of writing to introduce each recipe and how the recipe was laid out (extremely easy to understand). Each recipe is accompanied with sequence photographs to help you comprehend the recipe's techniques. I have already tried the stew recipe with dumplings, very good. We liked the texture and flavors and ease in which it was made. I am looking forward to trying out more recipes. Soon, I too will be able to "pass on" recipes to friends. The idea of "pass on" implies I learn a recipe from the book and make it and teach it to a friend who will then pass it on to someone else, thereby exponentially teaching others how to cook. :) LOVED IT!!!

I was very excited about trying out this cookbook because I like Jamie Oliver and his emphasis on healthy cooking, fighting obesity, and empowering beginner cooks to make great food. I only made a few of his recipes, some that I'll repeat and others that I won't. Hits: - Aloo Gobi - complicated (cook on the stove and then put in the oven) but it was tasty- Parmesan chicken breasts with crispy posh ham (prosciutto, yum!)- pan-fried glazed pork chops- Lentil Soup with Spinach (made with yellow lentils) Misses:- Chicken Tikka Masala (didn't have the right flavor)- Asian-style steamed salmon - not enough flavor- Bolognese sauce (not enough flavor - I had to add jarred sauce to improve flavor. Mark Bittman's bolognese sauce is better). The recipes were also not as healthy as I thought they might be. Maybe that's just my impression.I would have liked to try more, but alas, the book is due at the library.

This is a well-done beginner's cookbook with delicious looking recipes. The best thing about this cookbook are the pictures (sometimes up to 4 or 5) on each page, that shows the stages of the recipe, something that is super helpful for any level cook. The cookbook includes photos of people who have used his recipes and says how much it changed their lives. I liked the nice touches he used in the cookbook, like in the curry section where he explains how to make so many different kinds of curry and then in the back of the section, he includes easy recipes to make the sauces themselves at home (a good option). I liked the idea of the "evolution salads," teaching people the importance of having breakfast and the whole idea of the book is to get people to make healthier cheaper meals at home versus going out all the time. I plan on trying some of these myself, including some of the 20 minute and roast dinner meals, veggie dishes and the sweet potato/chorizo soup.

This is the essential Jamie Oliver cookbook and I'm proud to say that it has permanently sparked my love for cooking. I have worn the hardcover on this book out I've used it so much.The key to Jamie's success, especially in this book, is that he breaks recipes down so that even the most unskilled, clumsy, kitchen neophyte like myself can feel accomplished and like they did a good job with just a few ingredients.The Spaghetti Bolognese recipe is absolutely to-die for and has received endless compliments on how good it tastes and smells while cooking (a "too friendly" UPS guy felt the need to comment one evening). I always make extra because it's one of the few sauces I have found that is just as good after being frozen for a few weeks.The pages on Evolution Salad make what seems like a boring group of veggies delicious, as well as the other more adventurous recipes. Can't go wrong with Food Revolution, strip your cooking down to basics that are sure to please!

Jamie's recipes for dumplings, in this book, have turned out to be the best and easiest dumplings I have ever made.I have tried a few other recipes from this book and some didn‚Äôt turn out very well, probably because I tried to substitute ingredients to match what I had to hand rather than follow the recipe exactly. I think that if you follow the recipes absolutely bang on, even right down to the actual cut of meat, then of course you probably can‚Äôt go far wrong but I tend to use a recipe from a cookery book as a starting point and tweak it a few times until it becomes my own. Some recipes from Jamie‚Äôs other books have been through this process and have entered into my repertoire of tried and tested recipes. From this book, I would say it will be the stew and dumplings that makes it into my mainstay collection and his idea of adding marmalade to porridge was a revelation.

I may not be the best person to review this book, I consider myself quite biased. I have been a fan of Jamie Oliver for years now ever since his early days as the Naked Chef on the Food Network. I also have several of his cookbooks and have loved them all. ("Jamie at Home" is beautiful!) I loved his Food Revolution show that he did in England and was thrilled when I heard he was doing one here. I just got this book and already have marked several recipes to try. This is a great how-to book. I love how he has real people, not chefs sprinkled throughout the book. These are people that did not cook and thought that they never would. Now they are making their own healthy meals for themselves and their families. Hey, if they can you can too. ;)

I think I'm in love. Not only is Jamie Oliver a super-cutie, but he puts together an awesome cook book. I really liked the premise of this book; essentially that we all need to cook more to be healthier, happier, and save a little money. Now, I'm not exactly a novice in the kitchen, so I was a little concerned that this book would be too simple for me, but I think even experienced cooks would find some interesting information in this cookbook. I really loved how Jamie takes simple, everyday recipes, teaches you how to cook them, and then how to tweak them and change them up. I am definitely putting this on my Christmas list, though there's a good chance I'll break down and buy it before then.

I only had to watch two episodes of his food revolution to feel like Jamie was my best friend who I'd had over for dinner several times. I love to cook and I realized the more I know about cooking healthier the easier and better my family will live in the future. I can't wait to buy this book. It's amazing. I think the key for me is that I run out of energy to cook the vegetable after the main dish. These receipes have vegetables in them! Plus a lot of dishes that I make taste terrible. I'd love to finally learn how to make them taste good, vegetables I mean. There's a dish called Beef Wellington that looks good that I can't wait to try. A great mix of British and other international recipes.

There are many back-to-basics, eat more healthy cookbooks. What makes this one special is that it is so accessible, telling stories of real people doing just that; learning how to cook and eat better. The recipes look fantastic too and I can't wait to try them.For me, I love how Jaime breaks down salads and vegetables in paerticular. Too often when I serve them it is out of obligation-we all know that they're good for us-but not very tasty. I grow my own as much as I can, and while they're better, I've still struggled to find tempting ways to eat them!Ploenty of inspiration for that. I'm actually eager to make slads now thanks to this cookbook.I reads well, chockfull of advice and ideas, this one is a great book!

I'm not ready to review this book yet,mainly because I haven't made enough to be truly forthcoming about the recipes. But after reading some of the reviews...one in particular, I felt compelled to speak up for America's middle class intermediate cooks. So, Jamie if you are reading this, this is for you. I can't imagine an intermediate cook NOT knowing what zest is...lemon, orange, grapefruit or lime. I can't imagine not owning a grater here in the USA. As an intermediate cook, I can vouch for the fact that we own microplanes and zesters. I am a big fan of Jamie Oliver and I have to say that most of his cooking that I have seen on his shows and read in his cookbooks has been clean, simple and relatively gadget free...one of the things I like about Jamie's cooking.

Okay, so I haven't cooked a recipe out of it yet. I doubt I'll ever give Jamie less than, say, three stars even if he only shows me how to toast bread. After actually cooking out of this book I will likely change my rating. Yes, I am very, very biased. So I cannot give an honest opinion on the recipes (yet) but the book is beautiful as usual (though a bit offset by some of the pictures of regular 'ole every day people - the look they were going for and I'd rather see the food) and is made to look like an old, 1940's style book (at least by the wallpaper and props). I'm not talking it up very well. Trust me. It's great. It's Jamie.

I actually read this book, and enjoyed it. It's a library book, so I'll copy come recipes and save them. I made his roasted vegetables last night (potatoes, carrots, onions, turnips) and the technique is good -- parboil them first, then "chuff" them up in the colander before roasting, so there are plenty of rough edges. It worked very well. The book is a bit irritating in some of the terms he uses -- 'lugs' of olive oil, stuff that adds a 'twang' to the flavor -- and some of the techniques are not all they should be (I think you'd consistently get burnt garlic following his methods, but it's still a fun read.

I love the concept for this book, as well as Jamie's passion for bringing food preparation back into the domestic sphere by empowering folks to make delicious meals by themselves.On closer inspection, some of the recipes seemed slightly "off" for my palate, but this could be because the book is geared towards a British audience. Many of Jamie's recipes are also stick-to-your-ribs, no doubt delicious, but not the sort of foods I typically prepare in my home. I would highly recommend this book to anyone who wants an arsenal of tasty, easy-to-prepare dishes that don't require any exotic ingredients or terribly time-intensive preparation techniques.

"Jamie's Food Revolution" is honestly the most impressive cookbook I've bought in years. I absolutely love it. The recipes are delicious, the pages are beautifully illustrated, ingredients are common and easy to find, and the instructions are simple enough for supervised children and people totally new to cooking.Chef Jamie Oliver covers all kinds of dishes, from simple breakfasts to dinners that will impress even your prissiest friends. Curries, smoothies, salads that 'evolve' into 4 seperate dishes, soups, stews, pasta, and yes, even yummy desserts. I guarantee this cookbook has something for everyone.

I really admire what Jamie Oliver is trying to do--to teach people who have no background in home cooked food to become cooks themselves in order to improve their personal health and the health of their families. That said, alot of these recipes don't seem all that healthy--alot of fried food to start with. On the other hand, he does an excellent job of describing in great detail with alot of photos what you need to cook food (equipment) and what a basic pantry consists of (what do you need to start cooking)--and why, and how to do it economically, what your priorities should be and so on. It is a goos cause and a reasonable effort.

I'm an experienced home cook with a well equipped kitchen so I'm probably not the target market of this book. I found the use of shot glasses, teacups etc for measurements pretty infuriating and a bit of an insult to my intelligence but I guess there are some people that this would really appeal to.I've cooked several recipes from this book and they have all been really quick and tasty and so I'd recommend this book to busy working people. I'd also recommend it to beginning cooks. I own several Jamie Oliver cookbooks and one thing I like about them all is his 'style' - meals are generally hearty and not at all pretentious with an emphasis on healthy, fresh ingredients.

This cookbook features the stories of people who learned to love to cook on Jamie's Food Revolution, and includes some nice photographs of them in a home kitchen (not sure whether they're in their own kitchens or not). I've made a few curries and the roasted chicken from this book, and they all turned out well. Nothing has been stellar, but there haven't been any big misses, and it's a pretty book, so it's fun to turn to when I need some inspiration. I do find I tend to turn to Michael Smith, Williams-Sonoma and Gordon Ramsay before I reach for this book, though. It's good, but not great, and these days I don't mind a challenge, so I've been turning to more complicated dishes.

I like the idea that he presents this as a cookbook for people who don't cook, tells you what to stock your pantry with in the beginning, and then gives a bunch of practical recipes later on. The testimonials of real people who have learned to cook these recipes with no experience were cute. However, most of the recipes (aside from the roasts) didn't appeal to me or seemed too British in their approach (I don't really know what that means. I just noticed a lot of peas in everything, as well as some ingredients that aren't easily obtainable here). Overall not my favorite, but it might be great for someone who doesn't know their way around a kitchen at all.

Jamie's passion for food really shines in this book. I admire his enthusiasm for bringing a joy for cooking your own, delicious, healthy foods to everyday people.The recipes in this book aren't my fare these days (I can find gluten-free pastas, but dairy-free cheeses are harder to come by, and it's very meat-heavy) but that in no way diminishes how delicious they were when I started cooking them. From this book, I learned that bacon and cabbage are best mates, and that a fresh-squeezed lime over corn on the cob is mind-blowingly delicious. I've tried a few other Jamie books since this one, but this one's my favorite.

I have only tried a couple of recipes so far, but the book is organized well and is attractive. The text is fun to read. I picked up some new techniques that I have tried in daily non-recipe cooking. There are some recipes for 2 eaters, most for 4 to 6 people. On the whole, it really does seem accessible for people who don't know a lot about cooking - the instructions are clear and detailed and the pictures illustrate things beginners would like to know. For those who don't cook with alcohol, he doesn't rely on it a lot - just a few recipes include it. Overall, I felt excited about cooking while reading it and encouraged to try some things that are not usual for me to cook.

The recipes and pics looked lovely, but apart from a few simple breakfast dishes at the back of the book, most of this stuff was not for the beginner cook. I really was expecting truly simple recipes. I mean, I can cook, but my idea of a simple recipe is chop up a bunch of stuff, fry it, pour sauce on it and eat it. Or you get a bunch of stuff and water, put it in a pot and make soup. Or grilled cheese and tomato sandwiches. I swear I'm gonna write a truly simple guide one day, because cookbooks that claim to be simple and are not simple annoy me no end.

Jamie Oliver recently won a TED Prize for educating people (especially children) about food. I was very impressed and have been checking him out. Saw this at the bookstore and decided to try it. I've been picking recipes here and there from the book - depending on what I can get at the store. So far, I'm pleased with the recipes. I'm not a beginner cook but I do like easy recipes for everyday cooking. It's interesting to get a British point of view on cooking (although the recipes are somewhat Americanized for our market) and experience a different palate.

Ok, I didn't really read this carefully (I was trying to return it to my friend), but that is ok, since it's a cookbook. I think this is a very good choice for people who do not feel "fluent" in the kitchen. However, it's also a fun read for people who like to cook and who may find themselves in a cooking rut. I don't really think a foodie would find anything that is actually revolutionary in here, but Oliver wasn't writing for the foodies, and it's cool that he includes the little vignettes from people for whom learning the things in the book really did change their lives.

TCL Call#: 641.512 OLIVER JWow! A great cookbook for all skill levels. Jamie takes the terror out of cooking for hte newbie - explaining things like how to poach an egg. But he has gems for seasoned cooks including how to mix your own curry spices for his lovely extensive Indian food section (yes he has also a shortcut for newbies who can't fathom mixing spices!). The recipies are great and each one has a companion series of photos of all the steps required so newbies have almost a slideshow to follow.

This is the best cookbook I have ever read. I hate to cook, but as the mother of 2 I have been trying to learn. Years of buying and trying other cookbooks seem like such a waste. I wish I'd had this a long time ago! The recipes are simple, the several I've tried are delicious, all of the ingredients are easy to find. This book helps me cook in the way my family likes and needs to eat. Until I had this book, I used to truly dread dinner and wish I could just feed everyone cereal. Now cooking a meal is actually pleasant most days, and my family enjoys what I make!

I am a big fan of Jamie Oliver because of his passion for teaching people that real food can be easy to make from real ingredients and there is no need to rely so heavily on processed crap. He does this in a way that is fun to watch and his enthusiasm is contagious. I'm old enough to be his mom and have been cooking forever but I get fresh ideas from him. I did find this book is based on the tastes and eating habits of Brits and I would love to see some more North-American type meal ideas.

Riley (my 13-yr-old son) and I are very excited about this book. Riley says Jamie is the British Rachel Ray only not as cute. (We are working on getting him a better filter)These recipes are easy to prepare, but still have some new flavors--a whole chapter on easy Brit curries? Yes, please! A "posh" recipe that calls for a tablespoon of Marmite? YES! No more standing in the international isle at Meijer wishing I knew what to do with some of these neat-o foreign foods.Riley is looking forward to making some stews with "toppers" of puff pastry--very Hogwarts, we agreed.

lord knows i love me some naked chef. and i'm not gonna lie, his food revolution tv show has actually made me cry. this cookbook is good, not great. i think it's admirable to show that anyone can make easy, tasty meals that are generally far more healthful than what you'd find in a store. but maybe i've just been leaning too vegan recently -- but lots of his recipes are chock full of butter, sugar, salt and fat. again, far better to use these in non-terrifying quantities and enjoy them as part of a home cooked meal, but i wish that some of the recipes had been a little more healthful?

This is a good cookbook for intermediate cooks that seek to change things up. There is a variety of recipes from traditional English faire to Indian curries. For some of the recipes I needed to make substitutions as I didn't want to make another trip to the grocery store for specific items. I have made the granola recipe several times already as it is so good! During my experimentation I discovered that you can cut down the amounts of oil & syrup, increasing the healthfulness without compromising the flavor.

The recipes in this book are indeed simple yet delicious. Jamie tells ways to make a dish healthier as well. I have made so many of his recipes daily, twisted it to my style a bit, and I always come back to this book when I need to quickly make dinner. I see NO complication in his recipes, even if you're a beginner, unless you're just too lazy to learn to cook or to eat healthier. Read the recipe before you start, prepare everything. You need to give some efforts, the book doesn't buy you groceries and cook for you.. ;-)

Jamie and I have different views on what eating healthy means. Most of his recipes had some type of meat, milk, butter, or cheese in them. I made a total of 4 recipes so far, and I would not go out of my way to make any of them again. This is a beginner's cookbook, but what I don't understand is, one recipe Jamie will have you dump in 2 cans of chopped tomatoes, but the next recipe he will have you chop fresh herbs and add them to the recipe. If Jamie assumes you know how to use a knife in one recipe, why go lazy on the next recipe?

I loved his show years ago but then I moved away from home and didn't have a tv for a year. I've always had his words ringing through my mind. Real food is easy to cook. So when I found the book at the library I was excited. I was disappointed in the book. It is geared towards the UK reader. Lots of curry and traditional meals. But the Mexican corn wasn't even right. Lol. Don't get me wrong there are a ton of great recipes but only 4 would fit my husband and kids tastes. And I got the recipe aloo gobhi because of bend it like Beckham movie. Hehe.

Not a book for "oh, I feel like cooking today, what should I make?" but the perfect book for any less-than-confident chefs. Easy recipes, and plenty that use only ingredients you probably have in anyway. Perfect for when you're trying to figure out what to do with a seemingly random assortment of ingredients in the fridge, or for giving you new ideas for the seemingly never-ending supply of minced beef in the freezer.

Wow! A great cookbook for all skill levels. Jamie takes the terror out of cooking for hte newbie - explaining things like how to poach an egg. But he has gems for seasoned cooks including how to mix your own curry spices for his lovely extensive Indian food section (yes he has also a shortcut for newbies who can't fathom mixing spices!). The recipies are great and each one has a companion series of photos of all the steps required so newbies have almost a slideshow to follow.

I caved and bought this as Jamie is our chef for I Heart Cooking Clubs. This book seems to have a lot of simple recipes in it. The two I have tried so far are the Very Simple Curry (sauce) and the Lime-Cilantro Rice. I also used Jamie's recipe for "Perfect Rice" adapting it to use brown basmati instead of regular. Everything turned out well. Here's the link to my post with the recipes and pictures:http://kahakaikitchen.blogspot.com/20...

Great cookbook filled with lots of wonderful, healthy recipes. I love his emphasis on using fresh, organic ingredients. Vegans and vegetarians will need to figure out how to alter the recipes to make them plant-friendly, but, if you're willing to do the work, the rewards are worth it! I particularly like his sauce and dressing recipes - they're really easy to make and dress up some of the most seemingly boring foods in really flavorful ways. Highly recommend!

Very good cookbook! But don't be fooled...a "20-minute" meal is more like an hour the first few times you try it. But it's worth the effort and once you have made it a few times, it does become quicker and easier. Haven't tried every recipe but I have quite a few favourites. I believe if you buy a cookbook and you make at least 4 recipes over and over...it's worth the buy. This one is worth the buy!

The book I read was Jamie's Food Revolution but the cover and content is the same as this book. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who can't cook b/c it has step by step photos and lots of explination. Imagine the "Joy of Cooking" with pictures.I would also recommend this to anyone who can cook b/c the recipes look great and I'm totally going to make a few.

Excellent recipes, in particular the four different variations of stew. Easy, inexpensive and delicious. Watch JO try to dissuade USA kids from eating chicken nuggets by showing them how they're made...http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colb...

Another "broaden my horizons" book. I read through the whole cookbook (nerd) and found that I thought most of the meals were affordable, straightforward, but had a fun twist to them. We had roast chicken and yorkshire pudding tonight and they were FABULOUS. We're on to beef wellington here soon and hopefully will try out a few more of these before the book is due at the library.

1. The pictures are GORGEOUS 2. I've made a few things out of here so far, and everything is really really amazing. Easy to do, healthy, delicious, and relatively inexpensive. 3. Oliver is a funny guy, and that comes through. I would recommend this book to anybody wanting a good cookbook for simple dinners.

I heart Jamie Oliver. He is now my new favorite celebrity chef. The work he's doing with his Food Revolution is important and necessary work in this country. I'd love to just give him a big old hug - and then I'd ask him to give something a wazz in the food processor and say oregano for me (or-e-gah-no) :o)

A self proclaimed cookbook guru, I love this book! I keep returning to it, reading it, studying it, and of course making recipes from it. Jamie reminds me that good food can be simple to prepare. I've loved everything we've had in it, and am quite excited to make some of the curry dishes now that I've found Patak's paste. Yum!

This was an interesting read but I didn't find too many recipes in here that I would actually make. Maybe I'm too limited in my American tastes but I'm never gonna make curry paste or fish stew. I'd still recommend it if you like cookbooks, as it included nice pix of all the food and a story to go along with a lot of the recipes.

a really fantastic offering of easy, interesting, nutritious meals, cooked from scratch. so far all of the recipes i've tried have been winners. and jamie's step-by-step pictures accompanying each recipe are invaluable. a great starter collection of everything from italian to indian to american and british comfort foods.

Interesting book, he shows people who don't know how to cook at all how to cook simple, basic recipes. His idea is to use local fresh food as often as possible and he encourages the ones he teaches to pass the recipes along to others. It's interesting to read about the British and American "victory gardens" people were encouraged to plant in the 1940's.

I'm a fan of Jamie Oliver but, unfortunately I didn't see anything in this cookbook I wanted to make. They recipes look delicious but, most had too many ingredients for me and seemed a bit more advanced. I like quick, easy to prepare dishes with as few ingredients as possible. I'm not going to rate it since I didn't try any recipes and brought it back to the library.

I love that there is a whole chapter on ground beef. The recipes I've tried have been easy and tasty, although, as with every cook book I've ever used, there are a lot that we just won't ever make. The concept of bringing cooking back home is great. Most of the meals make way more than we can eat in a single meal, so I've had plenty of leftovers to freeze for a quick meal at another time.

I really was excited to get this book as I believe in his principles, however, there was not one dish that I copied to make. Either I had something better to make with the same ingredients, or what he used for a dish was not economical as a single person to have on hand or go out and buy fresh, particularly fresh spices.

Bought this book somedays ago, and I just loved the way Jamie makes the receipts looks easy to be prepared. I am not a advanced in the art of cooking, but I learned a lot with this book, and makes me always wanna go to the kitchen and prepare something new. For people like me, who didn't know the basic, this book is brilliant.

We've really liked everything that we've made out of this book. The cauliflower cheese soup was an especially big hit and I'm all for anything that gets my kids to eat cauliflower. The photos are beautiful and the recipes well written. One of the greatest things are the recipe basics with variants like the stew for example.

I don't usually cook because I live with a professional chef. This book is the one I regularly cook from, when called upon to do so. I love all of the photos of the dishes in progress for EACH dish, photos of all tools, and the steps are well set out. My favourite dishes from it are: the sweet and sour porkthe thai green currythe morrocan lamb with couscous

I love his goal of getting more people to prepare and eat real food at home. Great pictures, easy to follow instructions --it does take a little translation to get through all the britishisms, but it just makes it more charming for us linguists. However, many of the meals are too rich for my family (lots of dairy and meat)

I have given 10 of these as gifts and plan to give many more. Life altering and I love to give the recipient much more than just a recipe book. The entire concatenation of the process is magic. Teaching some one not to outsource their therapy, but to embrace the stimulating joy of creating, has found a perfect script in this book. Thank you Jamie Oliver!

I'm sure some of the recipes were good. I made chilli con carne and it was average. The language used is very Jamie-esque, which, watching a cooking show is very sexy. but in a cook book, no not a fan. I liked the concept of this book: like a pass it on mentality to cook REAL food. the food in there probably wasn't really my thing, so it went back to the library way before it was due.

Like all of Jaimie's cookbooks, this is great. It focuses on being easy and not intimidating, so it would be really good for a novice cook. But at the same time, the sheer number and variety of recipes is awesome. I can't wait to try some of the curries!

I liked the photography in this book because it was different that what I've seen in American cookbooks. However, most of the recipes seemed too fancy. The most useful section for me was the breakfast section, which contained recipes that were simple yet different.

Aaron and I thoroughly enjoyed this book. The chapter on curries inspired us to go beyond Tikka Masala and aloo gobi. We're intrigued by fish pie and kedgeree. A well done book with full color photos of each dish.

We made a ton of recipes from this book and every single one was yummy! They all had ingredients that were easy to find and everything was just nice and light and tasty. Our son ate from every recipe too. This will be for sure added to our cookbook collection.

I really like this book. Everything I've made so far has been quite tasty. However, I think there must be something different between his cans of diced tomatoes and mine. When he says, don't drain, do. Unless you come across a British can of tomatoes.

I admit I am usually somewhere in between admiring Jamie Oliver and thinking he's a twat. But, that being said, I admire his goal-getting folks to cook real meals-and of the three recipes I have already made out of here, they've all been keepers. So chAlk this one up as a win.

I love the idea of Jamie Oliver in theory. In practise, not so much :( I wasn't blown away by the recipes I tried in this book. I do love his idea that cooking should be accessible, enjoyable and a cultural experience. This book has beautiful photography.

I really liked most of the recipes in this book. My favorite is his ground beef wellington. However, I think some of the measurements are off when they were converting them. Whenever I attempt to make his potato au grain, they end up really watery :-(

This is my first Jamie's book. Compare to some of cookbooks I've read, this one is highly recommended for beginner cook because it has step by step pics for every recipes in it. The recipes itself are easy and nutritiously great. Pass it on!

I'm a big fan of Jamie's casual style of relating to food and passion for excellent quality food. The recipes and ideas in this volume are exciting and inspiring. A few typos and overly vague instructions- especially for a cookbook ostensibly for beginners-but overall a wonderful resource.

I like Jamie Oliver and this book has some great recipes. However, it is a different spin than his "Food Revolutinon" t.v. series (great BTW). I also like that he has started recommending organic, free range, and locally grown ingredient's too.

This is my favourite cook book. The recipes are easy, and use ingredients most folks have in the kitchen. I hate it when I have to go to specialty shops to get rare ingredients I will only use for a recipe I may or may not like.I wish more cookbooks were like this one.

A really great cookbook for those that are just taking their first steps into the kitchen. Loaded with great everyday basic recipes that are fuss-free and mostly healthy. I'll definitely be adding some of these recipes to my everyday meals during the week.

This is my new favorite cookbook. (And yes, I had one before). I love Jamie Oliver's approach to cooking and this book, for the most part, is just full of simple, yummy, healthy, cheap stuff (aka the food I want to eat)

Beautiful recipes with ingredients I can find at my grocery store, with a few exceptions (what is marmite?). I appreciated his philosophy about food and cooking from scratch. And the recipes. I have the lamb rogan josh on the menu for this week. Yum!!

I love the food in this book but have had to modify (or forget about) several recipes which are just too rich and too delicious, while we're losing weight. I do crave that beef and onion pie, though....

Good for beginners who aren't too fussed about healthy cooking. Many recipes are quick and cheap to prepare. The fare can be a little heavy and it's not too adventurous for the more advanced home chef.

Hands down one of my favorite cookbooks of the past few years. All of the recipes are fairly simple and straightforward and end up being pretty delicious. I like how Jamie throws in unexpected ways to use normal ingredients.

Surprisingly, my go-to book for Indian recipes. Whether you want to make curry from scratch or just use off-the-shelf sauces, these recipes cover many of the most popular types of Indian curry dishes.

I borrowed this from the library and will get my own copy in the near future. It's a beginner's cookbook, but I'd like to try to master the basics. His chapter on easy curries at home made me exclaim "YES!!"

I have several of Jamie Oliver books and have made several of his recipes. Colourful illustrations and easy to follow recipes. What I like is the fact that they are all easy to make and unlike many recipe books, are not too expensive to make.

My first Jamie book =)I got it for graduation.Every recipe i've tried i loved it, some of them didn't work from the first try but from third i even made changes that suit me better.Well written and super easy even for the people that haven't tried cooking yet!
Love this book, getting me into cooking. Made several meals from it, surprisingly all have tasted good. Highly recommend this book.
Well known food dishes in easy recipes with Jamie's signature. Gonna try most of them!
Jamie is such a cheeky monkey, this book is great for the kitchen challenged like myself. Breaks great reciepes down into simple, fun and easy instructions. http://www.youtube.com/DeadworldTV
Love this cookbook! It has great recipes for beginners that are packed with flavour!!
Fun for the whole family. Even my children can make "jamie's" spaghetti and hamburger!
Ideal for when you need something tasty in a hurry, with simple ingredients
This is probably the best of Jamie's cookbooks and I own them all. The most kid- friendly recipes as well. This book will always have a place on my shelf.
One of the best cookbooks I have ever read. I marked over 20 recipes right off the bat!
This was a great cookbook because it had pics for every recipe! I love that!!
Every single recipe I have made out of this cookbook has been amazing. Easy to make and tastes great!
I flipped through this and copied some recipes, figured there's no reason not to review cook books too :)
Great cook book! I really enjoy the pictures of the steps taken to create recipe. Easy to follow. Will buy this one for sure.
LOVE this cookbook! Many recipes are intermediate-level, but still totally doable. We've cooked several meals out of it and everything has been wonderful!
Holy crap I love this cookbook. Every recipe looks delicious and everything I've made so far has been divine. I'm in love. My FAVORITE cookbook. I wish I could buy a copy for everyone I know.
We are 4 for 4 so far with recipes in this book. I'm a fan of Jamie and his ability to make you think you can do it, too. Will have to purchase this one.
Great cookbook! Can't wait to make even more recipes from it.

In the introduction to Jamie Oliver‚Äôs latest cookbook Jamie's Food Revolution: Rediscover How to Cook Simple, Delicious, Affordable Meals, Oliver lays out his plan to get people cooking again by having them master at least one recipe from each of the fourteen chapters in the book. This is being called the ‚ÄúPass it on Movement,‚Äù and it is the young chef‚Äôs hope that it will get Americans back in the kitchen and cooking healthy food. The introduction even ends with a pledge that Oliver encourages his readers to sign; it‚Äôs sort of a promissory note intended to guilt budding cooks into actually passing on their new culinary knowledge to the uninitiated.Jamie's Food Revolution begins with a chapter on ‚ÄúEssentials,‚Äù which is basically a list of kitchen equipment and pantry items recommended by Oliver for aspiring cooks. I‚Äôm a serious home cook; I cook dinner at least six times a week and make most things from scratch, but Oliver‚Äôs lists intimidated the hell out of me. The chef‚Äôs intended audience for this book is the culinary challenged, those who‚Äôve been relying on fast and/or convenient foods to get them through their days. Recommending that these people invest in over thirty kitchen tools and gadgets in order to be ‚Äúwell-rounded, efficient cooks‚Äù can make them feel overwhelmed. Admittedly, many people have cutting boards, can openers, and box graters, but asking a new cook to invest in a food processor, food scales, chef‚Äôs knives, and other tools may be asking too much. The list of pantry items is also large; it features seventy-five items. Though I can attest to the usefulness of having these ingredients on hand for quick and delicious meals, it may alienate his core audience. Trying to convince an inexperienced cook they need five different oils is crazy, but I almost have to commend Oliver for trying.One of the biggest selling points of Jamie's Food Revolution is its affordable meals, but many of the recipes included feature expensive ingredients. For example, the first recipe calls for two filet mignon steaks, while others require leg of lamb, salmon, fresh tuna, and other meats and seafood. To me, this is just another example of a celebrity chef being out of touch with reality. This is only compounded by the fact that Oliver requests that everything be market fresh, organic, and free-range. The book includes photos and quotes by blue collar folks; all of them attesting to how these recipes changed their way of eating. Truth be told, teachers, single moms, and doormen can‚Äôt afford to feast on filet mignon, seafood paella, and roast lamb. I‚Äôd love it if everyone could eat organically and purchase produce directly from farmers, but it‚Äôs not realistic given the price range and availability of these items in most areas.One chapter that really fits the bill for affordable cuisine is ‚ÄúHomely Ground Beef.‚Äù Here we learn to make meatballs (moist and delicious), Bolognese sauce (rich and comforting), and chili con carne, which wasn‚Äôt authentic, but quick, simple, and tasty nonetheless.Enough with the criticism, let‚Äôs get to the good stuff: the food. Oliver, a recent recipient of the 2010 Technology, Entertainment, Design foundation prize, knows his stuff. Indian food has always been a mystery to me; it‚Äôs something I‚Äôve always been intimidated by and terrified to cook. Thanks to Oliver, that‚Äôs no longer the case. The chef provides recipes for five different curry pastes, revealing the secrets behind korma, jalfrezi, Rogan josh, tikka masala, and vindaloo. The first things I tackled were Oliver‚Äôs recipes for chicken tikka masala (spicy, curried chicken), aloo gobhi (curried potato and cauliflower), and light and fluffy cilantro lime rice. Except for a substitution for the chicken tikka (I didn‚Äôt have boneless, skinless chicken, so I used chicken legs), everything turned out beautifully and at the end of the meal I truly felt as if I‚Äôd conquered a fear.I owe a lot to Jamie Oliver. When I dropped out of college, I‚Äôd spend my days babysitting and watching his BBC show The Naked Chef, which I credit to helping me learn how to cook. Now that he‚Äôs revealed the secrets of Indian curry pastes to me, I‚Äôm forever grateful. I‚Äôm sure other home cooks will be just as thrilled with what the British chef has to offer.Review by Tina Vasquez
